qas.question: What is the term used when shifing the acent to the next preceding syllable?
Which dialects did not follow the Neoshtokavian retraction?

answers.text: Chakavian, Kajkavian and the Old Shtokavian

qas.question: Where can one look for memorization clues concerning accent positions?
What is the term used for shifting towards the orginal syllable?

plausible_answers.text: when the place of the accent shifted to the preceding syllable

qas.question: When did the quality of the accent appear historically?
What offers some clues for how dialects were different?
What did Chakavian, Kajkavian and Old Shtokavian follow?

plausible_answers.text: its melody still "gravitated" towards the original syllable

qas.question: What was different about the sound of historical linguistics?

context: <a2_0><b5_0>Comparative and historical linguistics<b5_0/><a2_0/> offers some clues for memorising the accent position: If one compares many standard Serbo-Croatian words to e.g. cognate Russian words, the accent in the Serbo-Croatian word will be one syllable before the one in the Russian word, with the rising tone. Historically, the rising tone appeared <b4_0>when the place of the accent shifted to the preceding syllable<b4_0/> (the so-called <a0_0>"<b3_0><b6_0>Neoshtokavian retraction<b6_0/><b3_0/>"<a0_0/>), but the quality of this new accent was different – <b7_0>its melody still "gravitated" towards the original syllable<b7_0/>. Most Shtokavian dialects (Neoshtokavian) dialects underwent this shift, but <a1_0>Chakavian, Kajkavian and the Old Shtokavian<a1_0/> dialects did not.
